Quote (translated):  "The decree on the work of educational organizations in the 2021/2022 academic year during the Covid-19 pandemic was signed by the chief state sanitary doctor of Kazakhstan, Yerlan Kiyasov.  The decree says:  Allow training in the 2021/2022 academic year in a regular format in educational institutions of all forms of ownership and departmental affiliation.  Akims of regions, the cities of Almaty, Nur-Sultan, Shymkent, the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan, heads of educational organizations of all forms of ownership and departmental affiliation to provide training in the 2021/2022 academic year in a regular format under the following conditions:  compliance with sanitary and anti-epidemic measures;  100% vaccination of teachers and staff (with the exception of persons with permanent medical contraindications who have recovered from Covid-19);  implementation of the Ashyq application at the entrance to the organization (registration by the QR code of teachers, staff, parents, visitors, students aged 18 and over);  observance of the mask regime;  providing a sufficient number of recirculators, sanitizers, skin antiseptics, disinfectants and detergents;  increasing the frequency of cleaning and disinfection of premises;  compliance with the requirements for wet cleaning and disinfection of premises, for the mode of ventilation and disinfection of air in premises;  daily "input" filter (thermometry with a non-contact thermometer) for teachers, staff and students;  a ban on holding mass events (cultural, educational, extracurricular and parental meetings, and others);  a ban on holding events in organizations of preschool and secondary education with the unification of groups and classes;  the abolition of the office training system, with the exception of laboratory, practical classes;  separation of students in primary, middle and senior classes (taking into account the maximum opportunity for the time of the beginning of classes)."    Archived link: https://archive.vn/m1MWC

As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk âRed Zones.â An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the âAshyqâ application system "    Archived link:  https://archive.vn/FCLxq

Quote: "International Travel RestrictionsVisa-free travel remains suspended. Authorities have also suspended 72-hour visa-free stays for Chinese and Indian nationals. However, flights with several countries have resumed, including Belarus, Egypt, Germany, South Korea, Kyrgyzstan, the Netherlands, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), and Uzbekistan, though capacity is likely to be limited.    International arrivals must provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry into Kazakhstan or a vaccination certificate. This restriction does not apply to diplomats, aircrew, train crews, ship crews, and cross-border workers; however, freight truck drivers must provide a negative test. Returning Kazakh nationals who do not produce a negative test or vaccine certificate upon arrival will be tested and placed in quarantine for at least three days. All symptomatic individuals will be hospitalized, while asymptomatic individuals must self-isolate for a further 12 days."    Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210926020833/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526306/kazakhstan-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-domestic-and-international-entry-restrictions-as-of-sept-20-update-47

Events  Events with fewer than 50 people, as well as religious events and funerals, are not subject to the certificate requirement. he organizers can, however, apply the 3G (vaccinated, recovered, tested) concept voluntarily and provide for a correspondingly relaxed protection concept without distances and masks. Private events are completely exempt from the certificate obligation and protection concepts.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011054028/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/

Higher education students and those in continuous vocational training who have not been vaccinated against COVID-19 and have no record of past infection will be required to test every 7-10 days instead of previous every 48 hours to be able to continue contact studies. The easing of the requirements will apply until 15 October. Services will also be provided in pre-school, pre-primary, primary, pre-secondary, secondary education, initial vocational training, non-formal education for children and educational assistance in compliance with safety requirements.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211001112021/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

Any gathering of more than 300 people is prohibited. Every gathering of 11 up to and including 50 people is subject to the condition that the people wear masks and keep a minimum distance of 2 meters. Meetings between 11 and 300 people can be held using the CovidCheck system upon prior notification. https://web.archive.org/web/20211005075331/https://covid19.public.lu/de/hygienemassnahmen/versammlungen.html

Any gathering exceeding 2,000 people is prohibited except they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate.  Any gathering between 11 and up to and including 50 people is subject to the condition that people wear masks and observe a minimum distance of 2 metres. For gatherings of between 51 and 2,000 people, seating must also be provided. Gatherings of 11 and up to 2.000 people can be held, with prior notification, under the CovidCheck system. https://archive.vn/0SeRo

For meetings at home or at private events, the general meeting rules apply. There are no restrictions or hygiene measures to be observed for private celebrations with up to 10 guests. For groups of 11 or more, masks must be worn and a distance of 2 meters between people must be maintained. Seats must be allocated for groups of 51 or more. https://web.archive.org/web/20211005075331/https://covid19.public.lu/de/hygienemassnahmen/versammlungen.html

For private parties of up to 10 guests, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed. For 11 or more people, masks must be worn and a distance of 2 metres between people must be observed. Private events with more than 10 people, without the need to wear a mask, the 2-metre distance between people or the obligation to assign seats, you must opt for the CovidCheck system. https://archive.vn/0SeRo

Schools and universities could be only attained with Covid-19 certificate or a negative test. Pupils who are vaccinated after the contact with an infected person is not obliged to is in a quarantine (only the test is required after 7 days).

As of October 11th Latvia enter the state of emergency, provisionally for 3 months.   Kindergardens and schools will continue to educate pupils in person regardless of vaccination status. Universities are allowed to give classes in person only to people with valid Covid-19 certificate (tests not allowed). Meanwhile, extra curriculum activities will face more strict restrictions. Education that is not defined as mandatory can happen in person in groups only among people from one school/class. Otherwise, classes should happen outside (maximum number of people limited to 20) or on an individual basis.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211014095000/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/aktualites/11-october-emergency-situation-declared-latvia-three-months  https://web.archive.org/web/20211013124935/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

No changes to policy, Yet given high number of Covid cases government has created three categories for service provider: unsafe (for general public), semi-safe (for people with Covid-19 certificates or negative test) and safe zones (for persons with Covid-19 certificates). As of now it is only the recommendation to do services in the semi-safe and safe zone, but the government stays open to change it if the number of hospitalised patients continues to increase.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210927075926/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Services in person are allowed only for persons with Covid-19 certificate or a negative test. I still code a 1 for C2, because together with this regulation there are more availability to do an antigen test (now it is easier to do a test at all medical institutions).   https://web.archive.org/web/20211004053129/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/apstiprina-rudens-epidemiologisko-regulejumu

In the private sector: the employer evaluates the responsibilities, specifics and circumstances of each employee's work, determining the risk of infection and the spread of infection. Persons who, according to the assessment, are not exposed to the risk of infection and do not cause it to others may perform work tasks without a valid vaccination, recovery or testing certificate. In public sector people without Covid-19 certificate will not be able to perform their duties.   Indoors restaurants, services and retail trade (except essential products) can be used only by people with valid Covid-19 certificate (with vaccine or recent recovery, tests are not allowed). Unvaccinated people can get meals outdoors as takeaway.     Indoors vaccinated people can only make purchases in these points of sale:       - grocery stores (with foodstuff being 70% of the assortment);       - pharmacies (including veterinary);       - opticians;       - pet food stores;       - press outlets;        - hygiene goods stores (with hygiene items being 70% of the assortment);       - telecommunications goods and service providers;       - fuel stations.    On weekends shopping centers are closed for everybody. Only essential stores are allowed to operate.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211013124935/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

Effective August 16, 2021, Moldova requires that all travellers present one of the following:  1) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 2) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  Any COVID-19 antibodies certificate or evidence of vaccination must be in Romanian, English, French, German, Italian, or Russian language.  Moldovan Border Police accept all types of vaccination with appropriate documentation.  Absent one of the documents listed above, a traveler will have to self-isolate for 14 days.  Self-isolation may be discontinued after 7 days if a COVID-19 PCR test or a rapid SARS-CoV-2 Ag test is performed, and the result is negative based on a confirmative document.  If you are subject to self-isolation and depart Moldova, you could be fined for violating self-isolation.   	https://web.archive.org/web/20211004192225/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Moldovan authorities established new public health measures to limit the spread of COVID-19 infection at all public events and gatherings, both indoor and outdoor. As of 25th September the government has announced a move to normal life.    Workplaces no longer have to close. But the government has issued this guidance for workplaces: "When to return to work, school, etc.:    Young people and adults should have a negative test result for COVID-19 before they return.    If the symptoms vanish completely after one day, they can return to work and school.    If symptoms persist, the person should stay home until their general condition is good, symptoms subside, and they have not had a fever for 24 hours without the use of fever relief medication. In most cases they should stay home for a couple of days.    If symptoms are more serious or persist, they should contact a doctor for an assessment.  If you have a negative COVID-19 test result, your symptoms are mild, and your general condition has not been affected, you do not need to stay home. Young people and adults can return to school/work when their health has improved or the same day that the test was taken if the reason for the test was mild or vague symptoms. You can return to work/school if you have residual symptoms like a runny nose or light cough."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001171155/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/norway-moves-to-normal-everyday-life-with-increased-emergency-preparedness/id2872539/

"Starting on October 1st, students are not required to use masks in school playgrounds (...) Masks are still mandatory in the classroom and throughout the building for students from middle school onwards.  When a positive case appears at the school, the prime minister referred the decision to the Directorate-General of Health (DGS) (...) the DGS confirmed that it is ready to review the two standards related to contact tracing and prophylactic isolation. These should be published within the next few hours or days."  Sources: https://archive.vn/lqDai https://archive.vn/lxs1q

"The prime minister, AntÃ³nio Costa, announced this Thursday the lifting of several restrictions, with effect from 1 October.  Costa added that the complete vaccination rate against covid-19 is at 83.4% and that, next week, it will reach the expected 85%, so the country will go from a state of contingency to a state of alert."  Measures that will come into force on October 1st include:  - Mandatory mask in supermarkets and other large establishments; -  Opening of bars and clubs with digital certificate. End of digital certificate requirement in restaurants, tourist establishments and local accommodation.; - End of closing hours limitations; - Restaurants with no maximum limit of people per group; - End of capacity limits, namely for commercial establishments.  Source: https://archive.vn/T0Qu1

Portugal is in a countrywide State of Alert. Under the State of Alert, the Portuguese Government can impose obligatory quarantine for individuals infected with COVID-19 and individuals deemed by health officials to require special medical observation. The Government of Portugal announced a phased deconfinement plan for the gradual lifting of restrictions based on the overall vaccination rate in Portugal. The plan, implemented in three phases, is in Phase 3.    Phase 3: Beginning October 1    Restaurants, bars, disco, cafÃ©s continue to function under normal hours at full capacity (with no maximum number of people per group, both indoors and terraces)  Max capacity at commercial/retail spaces increased (venue dependent)  Cultural events/shows continue to function under normal hours at full capacity    Presentation  COVID EU Digital Certificate will no longer be necessary to access:  - group classes in gyms, spas and spas  - restaurants  - tourist establishments or local accommodation  - gambling establishments and casinos    Presentation of the EU COVID Digital Certificate remains necessary to access:  - bars and clubs    Masks - Indoors: Mandatory while using public transportation, elder care facilities, hospitals, theaters, large event spaces such as stadiums and arena, public spaces such as shopping centers, and supermarkets.     Sources: https://archive.vn/gKHok  https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: All work areas are now open. However, bars and nightclubs require the use of the covid certificate, so the coding remains unchanged to reflect closures for people without a covid certificate exemption.
Policy remains unchanged.  Source: https://archive.vn/g7A6F

"The prime minister, AntÃ³nio Costa, announced this Thursday the lifting of several restrictions, with effect from 1 October.  (...) Costa added that the complete vaccination rate against covid-19 is at 83.4% and that, next week, it will reach the expected 85%, so the country will go from a state of contingency to a state of alert."  Measures that will come into force on October 1st include;  - Mandatory mask in theaters and events; - The digital certificate is still required for major cultural, sporting or corporate events; - End of capacity limits, namely for weddings and baptisms and cultural shows and popular festivals. AntÃ³nio Costa explained that spectators will be required to present a digital certificate in order to access "major cultural events", but it will be up to the DGS to define what these events are. On the use of masks in shows, AntÃ³nio Costa explained that it will be mandatory "whenever there is no distance of two meters between people"."  Source: https://archive.vn/T0Qu1
Policy remains unchanged.    Source: https://archive.vn/no2tZ

"The prime minister, AntÃ³nio Costa, announced this Thursday the lifting of several restrictions, with effect from 1 October.    (...) Costa added that the complete vaccination rate against covid-19 is at 83.4% and that, next week, it will reach the expected 85%, so the country will go from a state of contingency to a state of alert."    Measures that will come into force on October 1st include;    - Restaurants with no maximum limit of people per group;  - Mandatory mask in theaters and events;  - The digital certificate is still required for major cultural, sports or corporate events;  - End of capacity limits, namely for weddings and baptisms and cultural shows and popular festivals. AntÃ³nio Costa explained that spectators will be required to present a digital certificate in order to access "major cultural events" (...) On the use of masks in shows, AntÃ³nio Costa explained that it will be mandatory "whenever there is no distance of two meters between people"."    According to the Director General of Health "To access to cultural events that are held with capacity for over 1,000 spectators indoors (rooms or similar) and over 5,000 spectators in an open environment (outdoor events), the presentation of the EU COVID Digital Certificate or proof of negative SARS-COV-2 negative test is required."    Sources: https://archive.vn/T0Qu1  https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: Coded 2 to reflect the ban on the participation of those people without a proof of negative COVID-19 test/COVID-19 vaccination certificate in major events with 1000+ people.

"Before boarding, all passengers must present a certificate with a negative result of one of the following tests for screening of SARS-CoV-2 (...) Third country nationals without legal residency in Portugal will be refused entry if they do not hold a valid negative COVID-19 test or a recognised vaccination or recovery certificate.    (...) in addition to the COVID-19 test, passengers arriving from the following countries must undergo a 14 days mandatory quarantine in their homes, or in the places indicated by the health authorities and pre-register before travelling.?  India, Nepal, South Africa    (...) Passengers who have an EU-issued COVID-19 digital green certificate (EU DCC) or a non EU-issued certificate stating full vaccination or recovery from COVID-19.    The following passengers are allowed to transit through, enter and exit from Portugal:    European Union nationals, nationals of the of Schengen associated countries and their family members  Third-country nationals with legal residence in a European Union member state  Third-country nationals travelling for professional reasons, study, family reunification, health or humanitarian reasons  Nationals and legal residents of the following countries, provided that they are arriving on a direct flight or transiting only through the international area of any other airport:  Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Jordan, Kuwait, Macau, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Ukraine, United States of America, United Kingdom, Uruguay  Passengers holding valid EU Digital COVID Certificate or vaccination/recovery certificate issued by a non-EU country that accepts the EU Digital COVID Certificate are allowed to travel to Portugal for non-essential purposes.    Arriving to Portugal by Land  No restrictions of entrance.    Arriving to Portugal by Sea  Same rules as arriving by air apply.    Source: https://archive.vn/6ZQFt    Note: Coded 2 due to the fact that there are no entry restrictions in land borders.

October will bring a new phase of deconfinement plan which includes the reopening of bars and clubs, after more than a year and a half. This implies that these establishments will no longer be able to benefit from the simplified lay-off â an extraordinary regime that allows employers to reduce working hours or suspend employment contracts and in which the government provide support to pay employees salaries.   In August last year, this measure was only been available to employers were required to close (total or partial) facilities and establishments due to a governmental order. In March, the access to the simplified lay-off was made more flexible, also allowing companies fully or partially closed due to for example the interruption of global supply chains, or suspension or cancellation of orders, to benefit from this regime.  Bars and clubs that reopen but still face challenges, will be able to access, as an alternative, support for the progressive recovery. This scheme is aimed at employers with losses of at least 25% and provides support for the payment of salaries and allows employers to reduce the number of employees, however, this has limits that vary depending on the company's situation.  The Ministry of Labor also announced that the "lay-off" measure will not end and may be âused whenever there are situations of suspension of activities due to a governmental decisionâ.   Source: https://archive.vn/CPaXT

Sources: https://archive.vn/T0Qu1 https://archive.vn/8iGuF

Visitors must:    - present EU COVID Digital Certificate or proof of negative test  - carry out the visits at a previously scheduled time and with a limited time (not to exceed 90 minutes)  - respect the limit of visitor per resident or user at a time  - respect physical distance from users, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene  - use a mask, preferably surgical, during the entire period of stay in the institution  - do not take personal items, food or other products  - do not walk around the institution or use the users' sanitary facilities  - ensure that the visit takes place in its own space, spacious and with airing conditions  - visitors who test positive for COVID-19 should inform the local health authority if they have visited the institution within 48 hours before the onset of symptoms  - prioritise communication with the user via video call or telephone  - if visitors have signs or symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 or have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days they should refrain from conducting the visit    Source: https://archive.vn/no2tZ    Note: Code remains unchanged since the aforementioned measures apply to all visitors (who must present a proof of negative test/vaccination certificate - i.e. there are no exceptions)
Policy remains unchanged.  Source: https://archive.vn/g7A6F

The teaching process in pre-university education institutions takes place according to scenarios relevant set out in the guide for educational institutions, but a prerequisite for physical presence teaching is the presence of no more than 20 students per class. If in a class are more than 20 students, can work with scenario A (with class of halved) or with scenario B (combined lesson, where a portion of the students attend  distance learning. Selection of students who will attend distance learning (online) done in rotation every week. The teaching process in public and private university institutions takes place according to relevant guidelines, provided that the number of persons allowed in a class enables in  strictly maintaining a distance of 1.5 meters between persons.Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, by including preschool and day care institutions, must possess any from the evidence of vaccination, test or previous infection, in order to be allowed access to the institutions. All public and private institutions of all levels of education are prohibited organizing extracurricular activities, such as excursions, group walks, parties various of teaching staff or students. Archived link: /web/20210927174823/https://msh.rks-gov.net/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Masat-kunder-COVID-19-24-9-2021-2.pdf

Unless otherwise specified in this decision, gatherings on the premises of closed up to twenty (20) persons (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other collections). Participants are required to possess any of the evidence of vaccination, test or previous infection, in order to be allowed to enter these premises, as well as the organizer is obliged to provide a physical distance of 1.5 meters between persons and  checking the relevant evidence.  The Emergency Operations Center of the Ministry of Health may issue a permit to special, exceeding the number of twenty (20) persons, for events of special importance in the public interest. Regardless of the number of persons, the activity of night clubs as well as the organization is prohibited of festivals, concerts, excursions, pilgrimages, weddings, engagements, parties family and social, throughout the territory of the Republic of Kosovo. /web/20210927174823/https://msh.rks-gov.net/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Masat-kunder-COVID-19-24-9-2021-2.pdf

Outdoor cultural gatherings and events up to fifty (50) are allowed in person (public). The organizer is obliged to ensure the maintenance of a physical distance of 1.5 meter between persons. Regardless of the number of persons, the activity of night clubs as well as the organization is prohibited  of festivals, concerts, excursions, pilgrimages, weddings, engagements, parties family and social, throughout the territory of the Republic of Kosovo. /web/20210927174823/https://msh.rks-gov.net/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/Masat-kunder-COVID-19-24-9-2021-2.pdf

No policy change  Cafes, bars, and restaurants may now operate outdoor facilities with no closing time.  Indoor facilities may operate until 1:00 a.m.  Music is now allowed.  All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.  All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921090537/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/    Restaurants, cafes and bars are allowed to serve customers in their outdoor spaces without restrictions to opening hours, and indoors at reduced capacity, until 1am.  Retail stores may operate without restrictions to opening hours. Cinema screening start times are extended to 11pm, and box offices may remain open until this time.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210921090707/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/serbia/coronavirus    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921093921/https://covid19.rs/homepage-english/

No policy change    Testing can be scheduled for a maximum of 5 family members, if the desired laboratory receives more than one person at a time. Testing can be scheduled for citizens of the Republic of Serbia, foreign citizens residing in the Republic of Serbia, as well as for foreign citizens without residence (tourists).    Fee for RT-PCR testing for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 virus on personal request for citizens of the Republic of Serbia, for foreign citizens with permanent residence or regulated temporary residence in the Republic of Serbia, as well as for members of foreign diplomatic or consular missions and their families is RSD 9,000.00 starting from January 1, 2021, and for other foreign citizens the amount of the fee for RT-PCR testing on personal request is RSD 9,000.00 starting from April 19, 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921103358/https://euprava.gov.rs/usluge/6096

Partial reimbursement of wage compensations paid to workers by employers who are temporarily unable to provide workers with work as a result of the epidemic or because of force majeure  Partial exemption from social security contributions,  exemption from pension and disability insurance contributions for working employees  reimbursement of compensations paid to workers by employers due to temporary absence from work because of illness or injury  exceptional state aid for the legitimates (certain self-employed workers, religious employees, head of the (agriculture) holding farmer) in the form of universal basic income (UBI) in the amount of EUR 350 for March and EUR 700 for April  and EUR 700 for May;  social contribution and social security exemption for April and May for the legitimates (certain self-employed workers, religious employees, head of the (agriculture) holding farmer).    The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 percent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups.      Subsidying <50% is more common than >50%, therefore I marked "1".  http://web.archive.org/web/20210927191002/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available at Slovenian government institutions as well as private clinics.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required, but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 15-30 euro; cost for PCR is around 95 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.  Tests are not available at the U.S. Embassy.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210921095733/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Testing is accessible for individuals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210930085353/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Slovenia has administered at least 1,324,824 doses of COVID vaccines so far. Assuming every person needs 2 doses, thatâs enough to have vaccinated about 31.7% of the countryâs population. By the end of June, Slovenia should therefore reach the target of 60-per cent vaccination coverage of the entire population.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210920080102/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Restrictions on gatherings vary according to event type, with following regulations in place until at least 29 September:    - Party venue for private party: 50 people  - Other space or indoor area for private party (e.g. a bus, boat or tent): 50 people  - Party, private in home: Larger parties should be avoided and outdoors is preferable to indoors. Private parties in homes and gardens are not subject to legally binding rules.  - Funerals are always allowed to have 20 participants. This also applies if, for example, requirements for distance between parties would otherwise mean that there could not be so many.    Details for all types of regulated event and venue are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20210925031928/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/information-till-arrangorer-av-evenemang/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

20th September 2021, The Swedish Government has decided to ban from entering the country all persons travelling from Albania, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Brunei, Japan, and Serbia since they have been removed from the list of epidemiologically safe third countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210919213035/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-to-reintroduce-entry-ban-on-residents-of-albania-armenia-azerbaijan-brunei-japan-serbia/

Swedish citizens or foreign nationals who are registered or who have the right of residence can enter Sweden. An RT-PCR test is recommended on return for those who have travelled outside the Nordic countries, unless they have been fully vaccinated. When entering from certain countries, the Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends self-isolation for 5 days after arrival, unless vaccinated.     Foreign nationals entering from the EU/EEA must present a a vaccination certificate, test certificate, or certificate that they have recovered from COVID-19. The requirements do not apply if travelling from Denmark, Finland, Iceland or Norway. A negative COVID-19 test may be a maximum of 72 hours old upon entry. Children under the age of 18 are exempt from the requirement for vaccination certificates, test certificates and certificates of recovery from COVID-19.    A ban is in place for non-essential travel to Sweden from outside the EU/EEA. The ban applies to foreign nationals entering from outside the EU/EEA and is valid until 31 August 2021. Some persons with particularly urgent needs or who are to perform the necessary functions in Sweden may be exempted from the ban. Foreign nationals who meet the requirements for exemptions can enter Sweden if they can present a maximum 48-hour certificate of negative COVID-19 testing. These travelers must also follow the recommendations of the Public Health Agency of Sweden to get tested as soon as they can after arrival and five days after arrival. They should also isolate themselves for a week after arriving in Sweden. A number of countries are exempted from the entry ban.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210813050317/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

Tuesday, October 19, travellers from the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain can enter Sweden restriction-free, regardless of their vaccination status, the Swedish Ministry of Justice has announced.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211019072938/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-removes-entry-ban-for-all-travellers-from-uae-bahrain/

Government support for short-time working has been extended until 30 September, under which regulations an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. Employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. https://web.archive.org/web/20210716184304/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/important-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/short-time-working-allowance.

In Sweden, adolescents aged 16 and over are now also being offered vaccination against COVID-19. Children aged 12-15 years with an increased risk of severe viral infections are also being offered vaccination.    Vaccination is largely available even for non Swedish citizens in specific cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094003/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/children-and-adolescents--information-about-vaccination-against-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094027/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/cf2fc83a0b98452cb45cd4c4c63120e9/vem-erbjuds-vaccination-covd-19-engelska.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004094054/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/vaccination-against-covid-19/

Groups:    Pregnant women  If you are pregnant, you can get vaccinated throughout your pregnancy. However, the Public Health Agency recommends that vaccination be given after pregnancy week 12, unless there are other reasons. For example, you may have a medical risk factor such as obesity, high blood pressure, diabetes or are over 35 years of age.    Most people who become ill with Covid-19 experience mild symptoms of illness and do not need to seek medical care. But pregnant women have a slightly higher risk of becoming seriously ill. Vaccination against Covid-19 is recommended for all pregnant women, as the vaccines provide good protection against serious illness and reduce the risk of early delivery.    About pregnancy and vaccines from the Public Health Agency    Children and young people   All people, twelve years and older, are offered Covid-19 vaccination.    Each region determines how they handle consent when vaccinating minors. Some regions send a consent form in connection with the booking, others make a maturity assessment at the time of vaccination.     The Swedish Public Health Agency has decided to suspend the use of Modernaâs Spikevax vaccine for everyone born in 1991 or later.    COVID-19 vaccination for children aged 12â15, The Public Health Agency of Sweden    Those with immunodeficiency  If you are over 18 years of age and have a severely impaired immune system due to a disease or medical treatment, it is recommended that you take an extra dose of Covid-19 vaccine. It is your treating doctor who will prescribe the extra dose after an individual assessment.    The Elderly  The Swedish Public Health Agency ("FolkhÃ¤lsomyndigheten") recommends that people at increased risk of severe Covid-19 be offered a vaccine booster. This includes those who live in care homes, those with home health care or home care and everyone who is 80 years and older. The third shot should be taken six months or more following the previous shot.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211010054857/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn

Quote: "Authorities are maintaining international entry restrictions and domestic measures consistent with those imposed elsewhere to limit the spread of COVID-19 as of Oct. 4.   International commercial flights remain suspended. The only way to enter or leave the country by air is via a limited number of charter flights allowed to operate at Turkmenabat International Airport (CRZ). All land borders are closed until further notice.    Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and critical infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. Unvaccinated foreign nationals must present proof of a negative PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours and must undergo a 21-day quarantine in a state-run facility. Vaccinated travelers must self-isolate for only seven days and may do so at their place of residence.    Authorities test all international travelers on arrival regardless of vaccination status. While freight transporters are generally allowed entry, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must possess a negative COVID-19 test certificate signed within the previous 24 hours."  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20211008193456/https://www.garda.com/fr/crisis24/alertes-de-securite/531206/turkmenistan-authorities-maintaining-nationwide-covid-19-countermeasures-as-of-oct-4-update-18

As of end of June, Turkmenistan has used around 1 million vaccine doses to vaccinate all of their medical staff, public officials, teachers in schools and higher education, and elderly people. They are now in the process of vaccinating the population aged 60 and above.'    Archived link: https://archive.vn/NA3ft

Most services are available in Turkey without restrictions.  Starting September 6, 2021 proof of vaccination or a negative PRC test within the past 48 hours will be required to enter some establishments hosting crowded events such as theaters or cinemas. This requirement applies to individuals 18 years old and older including foreign nationals with Turkish residency.  Individuals who fail to provide the necessary documentation will not be permitted to enter into these venues or participate in crowded events. The wearing of masks is mandatory at all times outside the home throughout Turkey. This includes, but is not limited to, all public places, including streets, side streets, parks, gardens, picnic areas, markets, sea side and public transportation including Metro, buses, taxis and ferries. The authorities have softened access to a number of social support programs, such as household utilities subsidies and aid to families with children. The changes include (a) increasing norms (by 50 percent) for energy consumption used to determine the amount of subsidy; (b) stopping the disqualification from the household utilities subsidies program of a person that breaches qualification criteria; (c) automatic re-enrollment into the program for the heating season 2020-2021; (d) extending existing social entitlements for the period of the quarantine without the need to reapply; and (e) making private entrepreneurs eligible for the state support for children younger than 10.    https://web.archive.org/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#V
